channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-4430] Disable TestSlabCache and TestSingleSizedCache temporarily to see if these are cause of build box failure though all tests pass
item.summary: Disable TestSlabCache and TestSingleSizedCache temporarily to see if these are cause of build box failure though all tests pass

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
I did this to all tests in the two files:


-  @Test

+  @Ignore @Test
I just committed. Lets see what happens on next build.

Integrated in HBase-TRUNK #2232 (See https://builds.apache.org/job/HBase-TRUNK/2232/)
HBASE-4430 Disable TestSlabCache and TestSingleSizedCache temporarily to see if these are cause of build box failure though all tests pass

Can you take a look Li? It seems like TestSlabCache hangs up on hudson. See https://builds.apache.org/view/G-L/view/HBase/job/HBase-TRUNK/2231/console... see how the TestSlabCache does not finish...and then it fails the tests (though on end it says no fails or no errors)
Will do once I get in San Diego.
Got a test server I can try reproducing this on?

It passes on 'normal' machines but fails up on jenkins. Here are the test artifacts on a build that failed TestSlabCache: https://builds.apache.org/view/G-L/view/HBase/job/HBase-TRUNK/2230/artifact/trunk/target/surefire-reports/ Maybe if you look at output, since you know it, it might tell you something? Good on you Li.
Trace for TestSlabCache
The attached trace was the only hanging test run out of 601 iterations of TestSlabCache. The other 600 runs passed.
Marking resolved by hbase-4482; that patch reenabled these tests.
Reopening because TestSlabCache failed in most recent build – hung. Going to disable this test again.
I disabled all the tests in TestSlabCache for now. I looked at build output and there is nothing in the .txt and no -output.txt unfortunately making it harder debug.
Marking 'major' rather than blocker since this is experimental feature – shouldn't hold up 0.92.

Integrated in HBase-TRUNK #2309 (See https://builds.apache.org/job/HBase-TRUNK/2309/)

From Li up on IRC:


17:56 <li> something interesting:

17:57 <li> so

17:57 <li> under osx, the thing never ever fails now

17:57 <li> before 4482, we could get it to fail about 1/600 times

17:57 <li> under osx

17:57 <li> under linux, it fails every time

17:57 <li> for a different reason though

17:57 <li> heres a stacktrace

17:57 <li> http://pastebin.com/zsbGSy5P

17:58 <li> readbytes seems to be blocking

17:58 <li> i don't really know hy

17:58 <li> i'm not sure what readbytes is used for  - i'm guessing its part of mvn or junit?

17:58 <li> it would be funny if we somehow stumbled upon a race condition in junit/mvn.

According to todd, it looks something like mvn's stack trace. top
didn't reveal any other java processes.

I'll run this test again when I get home. I'm running ubuntu within vmware.

On Mon, Oct 10, 2011 at 9:57 AM, stack (Commented) (JIRA)
Tested, looped TestSlabCache 1000 times under Ubuntu. No failures.

This new patch synchronizes things a bit at the SingleSizeCache level. I do leave the copy to Slab, along with reads, unsynchronized, so it should give a performance advantage over Todd's super simplified patch.

If anyone was wondering, the race that occurred with the last patch worked like this.

Steady State: Item A is cached.
Thread B: Starts to cache something, starts eviction of Item A, evictionlistener is called, but has not been completed it.
Thread A: begins to recache item A, notices an entry for A already.
Thread B: gets around to evicting the entry for A, as it finishes eviction, wakes all the sleeping threads up so they have a chance to recache.
Thread A: continues onwards, sleeps the thread, and waits for something to wake it up. But B has already finished, and called notifier.notifyAll();

End result: A ends up sleeping indefinitely. Nothing notifies it.

I got rid of the jumble in the end. This should make maintenance much easier.

You have to change name of the file SlabItemEvictionWatcher to SlabItemActionWatcher since you changed the name of the Interface it contains (and its strange have a file named other than what it contains). How comes we can get rid of the block of code SlabCache. Similar in onEviction? Good stuff Li.

Right, forgot about that bit.

We can get rid of the block of code in SlabCache since I simply decided to synchronize things - as todd suggested. This felt easier than porting heapsize/metrics over to Todd's proposed patch.

I got tired of one race condition fix adding in another race condition. This was added in by 4482, which fixed one.

Minor comment, in SlabItemActionWatcher.java:


   * This is called as a callback when an item is removed from a SingleSizeCache

I think it should read ' from a SlabCache'

Please refresh the javadoc:


+/**

+ * Interface for objects that want to know when an eviction occurs.

+ * */

+interface SlabItemActionWatcher {
fixed comments
+1 on patch v3.
Applied 0.92 branch and trunk. Thanks for the patch Li.

Integrated in HBase-TRUNK #2346 (See https://builds.apache.org/job/HBase-TRUNK/2346/)
